p: In the cellular context, 2′-dG riboswitches are challenged by chemically similar compounds to their cognate ligand, the most similar being riboguanosine (rG). In rapidly growing E. coli, the intracellular concentration of rG is 1.6 μM as compared to a 2′-dG concentration of 0.57 μM ( 44). Measurement of the affinity of env1 for rG revealed that the aptamer binds this metabolite with only a 2.6-fold lower affinity than 2′-dG (Table 1). This contrasts with Mfl-IA, which binds 2′-dG with ∼30-fold (Table 1) to 50-fold ( 12) higher affinity than rG. To determine whether other class-II riboswitches exhibit reduced selectivity for 2′-dG over rG, we examined three other 2′-dG-II riboswitches with varying sequences within the three-way junction (Table 1). Overall, class II 2′-dG riboswitches vary broadly in their ability to discriminate between 2′-dG and rG, with env1 being the least selective while the env23 sequence has a far greater selectivity for 2′-dG than Mfl-IA. This range in selectivity is accompanied by a broad range in affinities, varying almost 2 orders of magnitude in 2′-dG binding affinity and approaching 3 orders of magnitude in rG binding affinity. This broad spectrum of binding affinities for the cognate ligand is similar to that observed in other riboswitches, such as the SAM-I riboswitch ( 45, 46).
